caption: Montmartre, with its rich history and artistic flair, is also home to the hauntingly beautiful statue of Saint Denis. Capturing the legend of Paris's patron saint, the sculpture depicts him holding his decapitated head in his hands, symbolizing his miraculous journey after martyrdom. It's not just a work of art but a testament to faith, resilience, and the city's layered history. Nestled amidst the scenic views of Montmartre, this statue is both a serene and profound stop, offering a unique blend of history and spirituality. A poignant reminder of Paris's deep-rooted legends amidst its modern charm.

The Statue of Saint-Denis, located in the heart of Paris, is a powerful testament to the city's rich historical and religious heritage. This magnificent sculpture stands proudly, depicting the legendary saint who is closely associated with the development of Christianity in France.  Standing tall and commanding attention, the statue captures the essence of Saint-Denis with its meticulous craftsmanship. From the chiseled details of the facial features to the flowing garments, every aspect of the sculpture showcases the skill and talent of the artist.

Statue of Bishop Saint Denis in a small park where is crowded with residents and tourists Saint Denis, the first bishop of Paris and patron saint of France.  In the middle of the 3rd century, he was beheaded on the hill of Montmartre and died.  This statue depicts the legend that he went down his hill, holding his beheaded head with hands, to the place God designated as his mausoleum
A small statue with a water fountain at its base is located in a small garden in the heart of Montmartre.

Statue that honors the christian martyr Saint Denis, is depicted holding his decapitated head. He was killed for his religious beliefs, and it was said that he carried his head after being decapitated and continued to preach the word of his Lord, walking up the present day Montmartre.
Overall the place was nice. However, the bathroom was disgusting.

Dionysius of Paris (in French Denis de Paris, in Latin Dionysius; Italy, 3rd century ‚Äì Montmartre, between 250 and 285) was a Roman bishop, venerated as a saint by the Catholic Church. He was the first bishop of Lutetia, now Paris, in what was then Roman Gaul. The Catholic Church venerates him as a saint, martyr and patron saint of Paris and the department of Seine-Saint-Denis. He died as a martyr on an unspecified date between 250 and 285 and the basilica and then the abbey named after him were built on the place where he was buried. The above is all that is known about him before the 9th century. Dionysius is one of the great saints of Gaul.

The statue of Saint-Denis watches over the bowling green and the play structure. The latter who had been decapitated by the Romans in front of the Temple of Mercury in the 3rd century, and according to legend, he would have transported his head in his buts to his burial place (in the current city of St Denis in location of the Basilica of Saint Denis).  On his way he would have stopped at this replacement where there was already a fountain to wash his freshly decapitated head.

If you walk in Montmartre, you can discover an atypical statue in the discreet Square Suzanne Buisson. It represents Saint-Denis, first bishop of Paris, represented‚Ä¶ with his head in his hands.¬†According to the historian Gregory of Tours, we know that, around 250, the Pope of Rome had sent Denis to Gaul with six other bishops to bring the Gospel there. Denis settled in Lutetia, where he was soon put to death by Fescennius Sisinnius, Roman governor of the province.

first bishop of Paris - Dionysus Your own head in your hands According to legend, after one of his sermons, he appeared before the pagan authorities and was sentenced to death. According to legend, after his execution, Saint Dionysius rose to his feet, picked up his severed head and headed north of Paris, preaching. At some point he stopped and showed the place where he should be buried and fell. The Abbey of Saint-Denis was built there  The park has a children's playground.
